articles.headline: Curing What Ails Starbucks
articles.snippet: Its coffee shops of the past are gone, but the chain can rebound by slowing down.
articles.abstract: Its coffee shops of the past are gone, but the chain can rebound by slowing down.
articles.lead_paragraph: To: Howard Schultz

articles.headline: Suitcase of Cash Tangles U.S. and 2 Latin Nations in Intrigue
articles.snippet: A spy mystery and diplomatic imbroglio began with the discovery of nearly $800,000 at a Buenos Aires airport.
articles.abstract: A spy mystery and diplomatic imbroglio began with the discovery of nearly $800,000 at a Buenos Aires airport.
articles.lead_paragraph: CARACAS, Venezuela  One day last August, an airport policewoman in Buenos Aires noticed something peculiar as she was monitoring a baggage scanner: the appearance of six perfect, dense rectangles inside a suitcase.
articles.byline: By Simon Romero and Alexei Barrionuevo

articles.headline: Escalating Losses Force Citigroup to Seek More Foreign Investment
articles.snippet: The financial giant is in talks to sell a stake to a Chinese bank and other investors, people briefed on the plan said.
articles.abstract: The financial giant is in talks to sell a stake to a Chinese bank and other investors, people briefed on the plan said.
articles.lead_paragraph: Citigroup is turning to cash-rich foreign investors for a second time as it confronts mounting losses on mortgage-related investments.
articles.byline: By Eric Dash and Andrew Ross Sorkin

articles.headline: Awards Season, and the Swag Goes to ... Few
articles.snippet: The Hollywood writers’ strike is threatening a beloved Tinseltown institution: the swag bag of free luxury items.
articles.abstract: The Hollywood writers’ strike is threatening a beloved Tinseltown institution: the swag bag of free luxury items.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif.  The Hollywood writers’ strike has claimed many casualties in the past few weeks, including this Sunday’s Golden Globes award ceremony, an important precursor to the Oscars. And now it threatens another beloved Tinseltown institution: the swag bag.

articles.headline: Debt Relief Made Harder for Homeowners
articles.snippet: Legislation pending in Congress could spur still more people to choose Chapter 13 to save their homes.
articles.abstract: Legislation pending in Congress could spur still more people to choose Chapter 13 to save their homes.
articles.lead_paragraph: Bankruptcy filings began climbing last year, as the housing crisis and rising consumer debt began to take their toll.

articles.headline: Bush and Congress Seen Pushing for Stimulus Plan
articles.snippet: Concern about a possible recession is bringing the president and lawmakers closer to agreeing on an economic stimulus package.
articles.abstract: Concern about a possible recession is bringing the president and lawmakers closer to agreeing on an economic stimulus package.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The Bush administration and Congressional leaders, increasingly concerned about a possible recession, are moving closer to agreeing that an economic stimulus package is needed soon, Washington officials said Friday.
articles.byline: By Steven R. Weisman and David M. Herszenhorn

articles.headline: Bank of America’s Chief Makes Big Bet
articles.snippet:
Kenneth D. Lewis has gambled on bold acquisitions, but 
few of his bets match a deal to buy Countrywide Financial Corporation.
articles.abstract:
Kenneth D. Lewis has gambled on bold acquisitions, but 
few of his bets match a deal to buy Countrywide Financial Corporation.
articles.lead_paragraph: Kenneth D. Lewis has gambled on bold acquisitions to build Bank of America into the nation’s largest bank.

articles.headline: Anxiety for Luxury Brands as Tiffany Reports Slowdown
articles.snippet: Tiffany’s weak holiday sales sent jitters through the luxury-goods industry, which had seemed invulnerable to the economic slowdown.
articles.abstract: Tiffany’s weak holiday sales sent jitters through the luxury-goods industry, which had seemed invulnerable to the economic slowdown.
articles.lead_paragraph: Not even luxury retailers are immune.

articles.headline: Inquiry Focuses on Withholding of Data on Loans
articles.snippet: New York State prosecutors are investigating whether Wall Street banks withheld information about the risks posed by investments linked to subprime mortgages.
articles.abstract: New York State prosecutors are investigating whether Wall Street banks withheld information about the risks posed by investments linked to subprime mortgages.
articles.lead_paragraph: An investigation into the mortgage crisis by New York State prosecutors is now focusing on whether Wall Street banks withheld crucial information about the risks posed by investments linked to subprime loans.
articles.byline: By Vikas Bajaj and Jenny Anderson

articles.headline: Obama Giving Clinton a Race in Her Backyard
articles.snippet: New York’s Democratic presidential primary on is shaping up as the most competitive since 1992.
articles.abstract: New York’s Democratic presidential primary on is shaping up as the most competitive since 1992.
articles.lead_paragraph: With Senator Barack Obama vowing to challenge Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton on her home turf, the Democratic presidential primary in New York on Feb. 5 is shaping up as the state’s most competitive since 1992, when Bill Clinton took up a rival’s mantra of change to all but cinch the nomination.

articles.headline: Cruel Jokes, and No One Is Laughing
articles.snippet: How banks could help, not hinder, sales by troubled homeowners.
articles.abstract: How banks could help, not hinder, sales by troubled homeowners.
articles.lead_paragraph: WHAT do banks call it when a troubled borrower abandons her home, sending them the keys?

articles.headline: No Quick Fix to Downturn
articles.snippet: Economists suggest that it may be too late to change the course of the economy over the first half of 2008.
articles.abstract: Economists suggest that it may be too late to change the course of the economy over the first half of 2008.
articles.lead_paragraph: As leaders in Washington turn their attention to efforts to avert a looming downturn, many economists suggest that it may already be too late to change the course of the economy over the first half of the year, if not longer.
articles.byline: By Peter S. Goodman and Floyd Norris

articles.headline: Iraq Eases Curb for Former Officials of Hussein’s Party
articles.snippet: A measure to allow former officials from the Baath Party to apply for government jobs came after months of U.S. pressure.
articles.abstract: A measure to allow former officials from the Baath Party to apply for government jobs came after months of U.S. pressure.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD  The Iraqi Parliament passed a bill on Saturday that would allow some former officials from Saddam Hussein’s party to fill government positions but would impose a strict ban on others. The legislation is the first of the major so-called political benchmark measures to pass after months of American pressure for progress.
articles.byline: By Richard A. Oppel Jr. and Steven Lee Myers

articles.headline: Having a Little Work Done (at the Mall)
articles.snippet: Customers are getting Botox shots in settings that are   more salon than  doctor’s office.
articles.abstract: Customers are getting Botox shots in settings that are   more salon than  doctor’s office.
articles.lead_paragraph: ANDREW RUDNICK snickered when he first saw a medical spa offering Botox and laser hair-removal services on a visit to a Las Vegas mall in 2002. He laughed at the thought of someone  anyone  shopping for the latest fashions, grabbing a bite to eat and then, oh yeah, strolling in for a quick shot of Botox to zap out a nasty wrinkle.

articles.headline: Across America, Deadly Echoes of Foreign Battles
articles.snippet: The Times found 121 cases in which veterans of Iraq and Afghanistan committed a killing in this country, or were charged with one, after their return from war.
articles.abstract: The Times found 121 cases in which veterans of Iraq and Afghanistan committed a killing in this country, or were charged with one, after their return from war.
articles.lead_paragraph: Late one night in the summer of 2005, Matthew Sepi, a 20-year-old Iraq combat veteran, headed out to a 7-Eleven in the seedy Las Vegas neighborhood where he had settled after leaving the Army.
articles.byline: By Deborah Sontag and Lizette Alvarez

articles.headline: Will Nardelli Be Chrysler’s Mr. Fix-It?
articles.snippet: A Detroit outsider faces an industry slump and a tough economy.
articles.abstract: A Detroit outsider faces an industry slump and a tough economy.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT

articles.headline: Huckabee Splits Young Evangelicals and Old Guard
articles.snippet: Mike Huckabee’s candidacy threatens to divide the leaders of the conservative Christian movement and their base.
articles.abstract: Mike Huckabee’s candidacy threatens to divide the leaders of the conservative Christian movement and their base.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Much of the national leadership of the Christian conservative movement has turned a cold shoulder to the Republican presidential campaign of Mike Huckabee, wary of his populist approach to economic issues and his criticism of the Bush administration’s foreign policy. But that has only fired up Brett and Alex Harris.

articles.headline: Toyota Will Offer a Plug-In Hybrid by 2010
articles.snippet: The move puts Toyota in direct competition with General Motors, which plans to sell its own plug-in hybrid, the Chevrolet Volt, sometime around 2010.
articles.abstract: The move puts Toyota in direct competition with General Motors, which plans to sell its own plug-in hybrid, the Chevrolet Volt, sometime around 2010.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT  The Toyota Motor Corporation, which leads the world’s automakers in sales of hybrid-electric vehicles, announced Sunday night that it would build its first plug-in hybrid by 2010.

articles.headline: Zagat Family Is Putting Guide Empire on Market
articles.snippet: A “clever and sharp” restaurant guide company with telling” rankings and “a penchant for quote marks” from its thousands of “in-the-know” reviewers is “on the block.”
articles.abstract: A “clever and sharp” restaurant guide company with telling” rankings and “a penchant for quote marks” from its thousands of “in-the-know” reviewers is “on the block.”
articles.lead_paragraph: A “clever and sharp” restaurant guide company with “telling” rankings and “a penchant for quote marks” from its thousands of “in-the-know” reviewers is “on the block.”

articles.headline: With Shows Like These, Forget Reruns
articles.snippet: Some bad news for striking Hollywood writers: Election 2008 is a breakaway hit.
articles.abstract: Some bad news for striking Hollywood writers: Election 2008 is a breakaway hit.
articles.lead_paragraph: I’ve got some bad news for striking Hollywood writers: Election 2008 is a breakaway hit.

articles.headline: Music Industry, Souring on Apple, Embraces Amazon Service
articles.snippet: At the Super Bowl next month, the music industry will be switching teams — from Apple to Amazon.com.
articles.abstract: At the Super Bowl next month, the music industry will be switching teams — from Apple to Amazon.com.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES  At the Super Bowl next month, the music industry will be switching teams  from Apple to Amazon.com.

articles.headline: Americans Cut Back Sharply on Spending
articles.snippet: A pullback in spending raises the possibility that the country may be experiencing a rare decline in personal consumption.
articles.abstract: A pullback in spending raises the possibility that the country may be experiencing a rare decline in personal consumption.
articles.lead_paragraph: Strong evidence is emerging that consumer spending, a bulwark against recession over the last year even as energy prices surged and the housing market sputtered, has begun to slow sharply at every level of the American economy, from the working class to the wealthy.
articles.byline: By Michael Barbaro and Louis Uchitelle

articles.headline: Fluidity in  G.O.P. Race; Democrats Eye Electability
articles.snippet: A new Times/CBS News poll underscores the volatility in the Republican race, and shows economic worries topping the voters’ agenda.
articles.abstract: A new Times/CBS News poll underscores the volatility in the Republican race, and shows economic worries topping the voters’ agenda.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Republican voters have sharply altered their views of the party’s presidential candidates following the early contests in Iowa and New Hampshire, with Senator John McCain, once widely written off, now viewed more favorably than any of his major competitors, according to the latest nationwide New York Times/CBS News Poll.
articles.byline: By Robin Toner and Marjorie Connelly

articles.headline: Race and Gender Are Issues in Tense Day for Democrats
articles.snippet: Senators Barack Obama and Hillary Rodham Clinton have been thrust into a social and political debate that transcends their candidacies.
articles.abstract: Senators Barack Obama and Hillary Rodham Clinton have been thrust into a social and political debate that transcends their candidacies.
articles.lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS  After staying on the sidelines in the first year of the campaign, race and to a lesser extent gender have burst into the forefront of the Democratic presidential contest, thrusting Senators Barack Obama and Hillary Rodham Clinton into the middle of a sharp-edged social and political debate that transcends their candidacies.

articles.headline: Wesley Snipes to Go on Trial in Tax Case
articles.snippet: The actor has become an unlikely public face for the antitax movement, whose members argue that Americans are not legally obligated to pax taxes.
articles.abstract: The actor has become an unlikely public face for the antitax movement, whose members argue that Americans are not legally obligated to pax taxes.
articles.lead_paragraph: From 1999 to 2004, the actor Wesley Snipes earned $38 million appearing in more than half a dozen movies, including two sequels to his popular vampire thriller “Blade.”

articles.headline: Big Weddings Bring Afghans Joy, and Debt
articles.snippet: In one of the poorest countries in the world, extravagant weddings are a mainstay of modern life.
articles.abstract: In one of the poorest countries in the world, extravagant weddings are a mainstay of modern life.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan  On the afternoon before his wedding day this fall, Hamid was sitting in an empty teahouse worrying a glass of green tea between his fingers, his brow furrowed in concern.

articles.headline: Trying to Fine-Tune Yahoo
articles.snippet: Yahoo’s chief executive and co-founder plans to expand the  Internet stalwart to make it “a starting point” for consumers.
articles.abstract: Yahoo’s chief executive and co-founder plans to expand the  Internet stalwart to make it “a starting point” for consumers.
articles.lead_paragraph: Jerry Yang began his biggest public presentation since becoming chief executive of Yahoo with something of an apology.

articles.headline: Europe Takes Africa’s Fish, and Boatloads of Migrants Follow
articles.snippet: Fish populations have been decimated along northwest Africa’s coast, fueling a surge of migrants braving the seas to reach Europe.
articles.abstract: Fish populations have been decimated along northwest Africa’s coast, fueling a surge of migrants braving the seas to reach Europe.
articles.lead_paragraph: KAYAR, Senegal  Ale Nodye, the son and grandson of fishermen in this northern Senegalese village, said that for the past six years he netted barely enough fish to buy fuel for his boat. So he jumped at the chance for a new beginning. He volunteered to captain a wooden canoe full of 87 Africans to the Canary Islands in the hopes of making their way illegally to Europe.
